EFFECTS OF OXYBENZONE AND OTHER CHEMICALS FOUND IN SUNSCREEN

Each year, up to 14,000 tons of sunscreen is washed off into the ocean. Wearing sunscreen is allegedly a healthy habit, however, it can have devastating effects on the environment, especially our oceans. Research has shown the exponential effects of sunscreen on marine life. In one study, conducted by Danovaro et al. (2008), it was found that even in small doses, sunscreen can be deadly. The researcher applied the recommended amount of sunscreen to volunteers' hands and had the volunteers immerse their hands into 2L containers containing various species of coral. Within 96 hours, all of the coral exposed to the sunscreen were completely bleached.

 Oxybenzone (BP-3) and octinoxate are two of the popular of many harmful chemicals found in 3,500+ skin care products worldwide. These chemicals are highly toxic to juvenile corals and other marine life and can enter the environment through both wastewater and directly from swimmers wearing sunscreen. Research has shown four major toxic effects in coral: increased susceptibility to bleaching, DNA damage, abnormal skeleton growth, and gross deformities of baby coral.

In addition to damaging coral, sunscreen chemicals can have devastating effects on algae, fish, and even dolphins.
